Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michael Okyen of Virginia Tech to conduct a research project, entitled "Slip and slide: balance control to prevent sliding and twisting of the feet of humanoid robots," during the summer of 2012 at the Korea Institute of Science and Technology in Seoul, Seongbuk-gu, Korea. The host scientist is Dr. Bum-Jae You.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to develop a method to improve the balance of a humanoid robot. The goal of many robotic systems is to take over human tasks in everyday environments, where surfaces greatly vary. However, few can actually adapt to the variations and therefore cannot reliably begin their role in society.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a recipient of the NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute 2012 grant, I traveled to the Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) in Seoul where I joined the Interaction and Robotics Research Center. My work at KIST focused on examining Mahru, a robot developed since 2004 and considered one of the most advanced humanoid robots in the world today. In particular, I worked with researchers to understand the intricacies of their mechanical design and the balancing/walking algorithm employed by Mahru. This experience served as a guide to make significant revisions to improve the design of the robotic legs I was developing as the central focus of my Master’s degree research in Mechanical Engineering at Virginia Tech, which I defended in April 2013.

By working with a large, mature laboratory at KIST, I gained significant experience in robotic mechanical design, system modeling, electrical wiring, and software design, which I brought back to my research group at Virginia Tech. My KIST professors and lab mates possessed extensive knowledge of humanoids and maintained contact with robotics researchers worldwide, both of which expanded my understanding of the development and evolution of the humanoid robotics field. This served as an integral part of my Master’s thesis in which I surveyed walking robots from across the globe, and is the topic of a manuscript currently in progress.

In addition to the scientific knowledge I gained, I was also able to bring the cultural experience to my martial arts club at Virginia Tech, where we study the Korean art of Tang Soo Do. Serving as the head instructor and club president, I was able to connect the philosophy of techniques and customs of Tang Soo Do to the society that cultivated them. Additionally, as a research institute, KIST offered the unique experience of daily interactions with researchers not only from Korea, but hailing internationally, and through those relationships I gained an appreciation for global politics and a greater understanding of the role and perception of the United States. My experience as an EAPSI Fellow made a tremendous impact on my life; it expanded my skills as an engineer, enlightened me to my place in the world, and pushed me to grow as person as I began my transition from formal schooling to the professional world.
